title: Have you read the novel “Bringing the Nation’s Husband Home” on Webnovel? Is it good? What is your opinion about it? - Quora
tags: Bringing the Nation’s Husband Home (web novel)

response.answer_text: **There might be some spoilers ahead** Yes, I have read part of “Bringing the Nation’s Husband Home.” It’s already a completed book but I didn’t finish it. I think I got until 300+ chapters before dropping it, if I remember it right. What do I think about it? The English translation was great. Very minimal grammatical errors, almost negligible. The world setting was in modern day China that involves the entertainment industry which is typical for this kind of novel, nothing new but it was okay. Character design and story development, on the other hand, I find them frustrating though. Why? Let me start with the synopsis of the story which is as follows: Qiao Anhao and Lu Jinnian had secretly longed for each other for thirteen years, and now that there's a possibility for them to be together, even though the circumstances may be unconventional, neither one can refuse their inner desires any longer. Hurled into a false marriage, Qiao Anhao treads carefully towards the cold and reclusive Lu Jinnian, but after years of near-missed opportunities and deep misunderstandings, how could their last shot at love possibly run smooth? **"Nation Husband" is a Korean term awarded to a man who is perfect in the eyes of the public - an ideal husband. Source: Webnovel Keywords there are: secretly longed for each other for thirteen years, false marriage, years of near-missed opportunities and deep misunderstandings Just from those keywords alone, it’s safe to expect a tragic, heavy drama love story. It was indeed tragic, it was indeed dramatic, and it was a love story. But a little bit too much tragedy and too much drama for my taste. I mean, most of the complications they had could’ve been avoided if they just TALKED. Like two proper adults. I get that there are “big” and “small” complications in a story, but even the smallest things were blown up because they couldn’t properly communicate. Ugh! To be fair though, from the beginning until the first hundred chapters showing their “near-missed opportunities” really moved me. I literally was crying my eyes out for them! How tragic! How dramatic! I was full on sympathetic. But then, a few hundred more chapters later and they still have no progress in their relationship! Why?! I just don’t get it anymore! I mean, they are supposedly married, although fake, with the person they have been in love with for more than a freaking decade! And then what? They can’t even have a proper conversation with each other without hurting and insulting one another. That was when the story gets frustrating for me. Really frustrating. It was no longer a case of “near-missed opportunities” but rather the Female and Male Leads acting like perfect idiots. The tragedy and the drama, they are bringing it on to themselves. I got so frustrated and tired of it and could not go on reading more of their freaking love story. If you have better tolerance than I do or prefer that kind of stories, then that would be a good story to read. If you are into strong FLs and MLs though, I would suggest giving “Full Marks Hidden Marriage: Pick Up a Son, Get a Free Husband” a try.

In my opinion, it wasn’t that great. I tried reading the novel itself—got to chapter 500 through sheer force of will, and I even tried reading the webtoon/manga version of the story. But the Male Lead is just too...antagonistic for me. He jumps to conclusions and makes irrational decisions too quickly. Meanwhile, the Female Lead is too subservient. The entire book is a thousand chapters based around a miscommunication, and with all the things these two have done to each other in retaliation, it’s a wonder they end up together at all. If you want a more powerful female lead, I suggest “Perfect Secret Love: The Bad New Wife is a Little Sweet,” “Travelling to the Future, It’s Not Easy to be a Man,” “Anarchic Consort,” or “Mesmerizing Ghost Doctor.” (Also, check out “The Experimental Log of a Crazy Lich,” or “The Daily Life of an Immortal King,” if you want hilarious characters and ridiculous adventures.)
